Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Effects of Wood-Boring and Fouling Marine Invertebrates to the Productivity, Morphology, and Integrity of Taiwanese Mangroves

POR.DRECONTENT:
The destruction and alteration of mangroves infested by a wood-boring crustacean in a restored mangrove stand in Taiwan

Mangrove forests are important transition zones between terrestrial and marine ecosystems in the tropics and sub-tropics. These saltwater tolerant trees link marine and terrestrial ecosystems together allowing the exchange of nutrients, marine and terrestrial species, and other resources. Mangroves are also important for their ecosystem services such as buffering storm damage, reducing pollution, and providing habitat for ecological and economically important species.  Because mangroves live at the interface of land and sea, many organisms can affect them. Wood-boring species, in particular, can damage trees and reduce the productivity and fitness of mangroves. While previous research has investigated how boring isopod crustaceans alter root growth, studies have not examined how these isopods may affect tree level measurements of health. To investigate the potential effects of a wood-boring isopod crustacean (Sphaeroma terebrans) in a tropical mangrove stand in Taiwan, I conducted a field experiment in collaboration with the laboratory of Hwey-Lian Hsieh (at Academia Sinica).  I sampled thirty eight mangrove trees in the Haomeiliao Nature Preserve (28 Avicennia marina trees, 10 Rhizophora stylosa trees) to characterize how burrowing by isopods is related to root damage, tree morphology, and fitness.

The mangrove trees in Haomeiliao were extensively damaged by the wood-boring isopod (Sphaeroma terebrans; Figure 1); 95% of the Avicennia marina and 100% of Rhizophora stylosa trees examined were infested. In some A. marina trees, damage by isopods could be extensive (Figure 2). Trees that were more heavily burrowed appeared to have many discolored leaves and a lower leaf cover. More heavily burrowed A. marina also had smaller, shorter, and more damaged pneumatophores (pencil-like roots used for gaseous exchange). Likewise, I found a weak negative relationship between burrow numbers and the number of lenticels on pneumatophores. Lenticels (pores used for oxygen exchange) are essential for survivorship of plants in the oxygen-deficient water-logged soil. Greater damage to pneumatophores and fewer lenticels may make the tree less capable of tolerating the oxygen-deficient conditions. Similarly, boring by isopods in the free-hanging aerial roots of R. stylosa also appeared to lower the stability of the trees. With the supportive roots destroyed, some trees fell over (Figure 3) or were close to falling over. In R. stylosa, I found that trees with more burrowed aerial roots (Figure 4) also had fewer aerial roots that were grounded and anchored into the sediment. Since these grounded roots are essential to anchoring the tree into the ground, fewer grounded roots may make the tree more prone to falling. My results also indicated that trees that were more heavily burrowed by isopods had less propagules (germinated seeds still attached to tree) and less leaves.

The results from this work suggest that wood-borers can negatively influence mangrove fitness and thus the success of mangrove restoration efforts. Even though isopod borers only create small burrows in mangroves, this minor individual boring effect can have a large cumulative effect on mangrove trees. Thus, small organisms, in dense aggregations, can alter the structure and function of an important marine habitat. The results of this study may also be important for future mangrove restoration efforts. The success of future mangrove restoration projects would be enhanced if restoration managers examined the local mangrove sites for evidence of wood-borers.
